title: Bitmap Derived Fonts
content:
I’ve just come across “bitfaux” ( [http://soteropolitypes.net/font\_bitfaux.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905082556/http:/soteropolitypes.net/font_bitfaux.htm "http://soteropolitypes.net/font\_bitfaux.htm")). What other examples of this sort are out there? (Fonts that include smooth curves yet clearly reference bitmap edges.)

 [‹ Good New Wave books?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905082556/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41874 "Go to previous forum topic") [Hidden Typography exposed ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905082556/http:/www.typophile.com/node/1971 "Go to next forum topic")
author: tupper

comments.content:
This is a bit off, but the ultimate bitmap derived fonts are Verdana and Georgia. Obviously not what you were looking for, but interesting nonetheless.

Perhaps [Doppil](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905082556/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/dopil.asp)?

Not fonts, but some beautiful hand lettering by Marian.

This one immediately springs to mind – [Citizen](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905082556/http:/www.emigre.com/EF.php?fid=85) by [Zuzana Licko](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905082556/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Zuzana%252BLicko)

«Autoscape» was developed from an existing design by Andrew Welch, Carl R. Osterwald, Stephen Gilardi and William I. Johnston, which in turn was based on the 9-point bitmap of the standard «Monaco» font. — [Lineto](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905082556/http:/lineto.com/The+Fonts/Font+Categories/Text+Fonts/AutoScape/About+this+Font/)
